sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The Caching Module provides a consistent abstraction for caching, delivering the following benefits:

listitem.para: Provides declarative caching services powered by Spring AOP and enabled by these two advices:
org.springmodules.cache.interceptor.caching.CachingInterceptor. Stores in the cache the return values of the advised methods.
org.springmodules.cache.interceptor.flush.CacheFlushInterceptor. Flushes the cache or parts of the cache before or after executing the advised methods.

Caching services can be defined completely in the Spring configuration file. Optionally, caching services can be enabled using source-level metadata, providing a similar programming model to .NET ServicedComponents.

Automatically generates the key of the entries stored in the cache by combining the hash codes of the advised method and its arguments. Custom key generators can be created by implementing the interface org.springmodules.cache.key.CacheKeyGenerator.
Lets the user choose a cache provider that better suites the needs of a particular project. The supported cache providers are:
EHCache.
JCS.
OSCache.
Easy to extend to support additional cache providers.

sect1.title: Uses
sect1.para: Caching services can be used to improve application performance. A very common example is the caching of data retrieved from a database. Even though ORM frameworks such as iBATIS and Hibernate already provide built-in caching, the Caching Module can be useful when:

listitem.para: Executing methods that perform heavy calculations, are time-consuming and/or are resource-hungry.
When using straight JDBC, Spring JDBC, or any ORM framework that does not support caching.
When you want to choose the cache provider to use and/or you want to have more control on the cache.

sect1.title: Configuration
sect1.para: Please follow the following steps to configure caching and cache-flushing:

listitem.para: Set up the cache provider. Instead of imposing the use of a particular cache implementation, the Caching Module lets you choose a cache provider that better suites the needs of your project.
Enable the caching services. The Caching Module provides two ways to enable the caching services:
Declarative caching services (via Spring AOP).
Programmatic use (via a single interface, org.springmodules.cache.provider.CacheProviderFacade).

sect2.title: Set up the Cache Provider
sect2.para: The Caching Module provides a common interface that contains and centralizes the interactions with the underlying cache provider. Each facade must implement the interface org.springmodules.cache.provider.CacheProviderFacade or subclass the template org.springmodules.cache.provider.AbstractCacheProviderFacadeImpl.
All the provided facades have these common properties:

listitem.para: cacheManager (required). A cache manager administrates the cache. In general, a cache manager should be able to:
Store objects in the cache.
Retrieve objects from the cache.
Remove objects from the cache.
Flush or invalidate the cache.

The cache manager can be replaced by a factory that creates a singleton instance of the cache manager. Such factory allows custom configuration of the cache manager (depending on the cache provider) and ensures that the Spring container shuts down the cache manager when the factory is destroyed by the BeanFactory.

The Caching Module supplies factories for the supported cache providers. (with the exception of EHCache, which is provided by the Spring Framework). Each factory may subclass org.springmodules.cache.provider.AbstractSingletonCacheManagerFactoryBean or, org.springmodules.cache.provider.AbstractConfigurationResourceCacheManagerFactoryBean if the factory uses a configuration file to create the cache manager.
cacheProfiles (required). A cache profile tells the cache provider how to cache objects and how to flush the cache. Cache profiles can be defined as a:

java.util.Map. This is the conventional way of setting up a map as a property of a bean definition. Since each entry of the map must be defined as a bean, we could end up with an excessively long and verbose configuration file.

java.util.Properties. This is an alternative, simplified way to set up the cache profiles. Each cache profile is defined as a string of the form "[propertyName1=propertyValue1][propertyName2=propertyValue2]" where each of the properties of the cache profile is specified between brackets. The fully qualified class name is not necessary because the facade chooses the class of the cache profile that is suitable for the chosen cache provider
failQuietlyEnabled (optional). Indicates if an exception should thrown or not when an error occurrs when accessing the cache. The default value is false.

sect3.title: EHCache
sect3.para: The cache manager is a singleton instance of net.sf.ehcache.CacheManager created by the bean factory org.springframework.cache.ehcache.EhCacheManagerFactoryBean.

para.emphasis: Please refer to the EHCache documentation for more information. Also, Omar Irbouh wrote an interesting article about using EHCache with Spring.

para.programlisting:
<bean id="cacheProvider" class="org.springmodules.cache.provider.ehcache.EhcacheFacade"> <property name="cacheManager" ref="cacheManager" />
<!-- Cache profiles specified as a java.util.Map --> <property name="cacheProfiles"> <map> <entry key="test"> <bean class="org.springmodules.cache.provider.ehcache.EhcacheCacheProfile"> <property name="cacheName" value="testCache" /><!-- Required --> </bean> </entry> </map> </property>
<!-- Same cache profiles specified as a java.util.Properties --> <property name="cacheProfiles"> <props> <prop key="test">[cacheName=testCache]</prop> </props> </property> </bean>

sect3.title: JCS
sect3.para: The cache manager is a singleton instance of org.apache.jcs.engine.control.CompositeCacheManager created by the bean factory org.springmodules.cache.provider.jcs.JcsCacheManagerFactoryBean.

para.emphasis: Please refer to the JCS documentation for more information.

para.programlisting:
<bean id="cacheProvider" class="org.springmodules.cache.provider.jcs.JcsFacade"> <property name="cacheManager" ref="cacheManager" />
<!-- Cache profiles specified as a java.util.Map --> <property name="cacheProfiles"> <map> <entry key="test"> <bean class="org.springmodules.cache.provider.jcs.JcsCacheProfile"> <property name="cacheName" value="testCache" /><!-- Required --> <property name="group" value="testGroup" /><!-- Optional --> </bean> </entry> </map> </property>
<!-- Same cache profiles specified as a java.util.Properties --> <property name="cacheProfiles"> <props> <prop key="test">[cacheName=testCache][group=testGroup]</prop> </props> </property> </bean>

sect3.title: OSCache
sect3.para: The cache manager is a singleton instance of com.opensymphony.oscache.general.GeneralCacheAdministrator created by the bean factory org.springmodules.cache.provider.oscache.OscacheManagerFactoryBean.

para.emphasis: Please refer to the OSCache documentation for more information. Rob Harrop posted in the Spring Wiki a much simpler way to set up OSCache with Spring.

para.programlisting:
<bean id="cacheProvider" class="org.springmodules.cache.provider.oscache.OscacheFacade"> <property name="cacheManager" ref="cacheManager" />
<!-- Cache profiles specified as a java.util.Map --> <property name="cacheProfiles"> <map> <entry key="test"> <bean class="org.springmodules.cache.provider.oscache.OscacheCacheProfile"> <property name="cronExpression" value="* * * * *" /><!-- Optional --> <property name="groups" value="group1,group2" /><!-- Optional --> <property name="refreshPeriod" value="600" /><!-- Optional --> </bean> </entry> </map> </property>
<!-- Same cache profiles specified as a java.util.Properties --> <property name="cacheProfiles"> <props> <prop key="test">[cronExpression=* * * * *][groups=group1,group2][refreshPeriod=600]</prop> </props> </property> </bean>

sect2.title: Declarative Caching Services
sect2.para: The Caching Module provides different ways to create proxies to enable the caching services:

listitem.para: Proxy Factory. The factory org.springmodules.cache.interceptor.proxy.CacheProxyFactoryBean creates a proxy for a single bean definition. By using the proxy factory all the configuration details for the caching services are declared in the Spring configuration file.

Metadata-driven Autoproxy. Autoproxying is driven by metadata. This produces a similar programming model to .NET ServicedComponents. Proxies for caching services are created automatically for the bean definition(s) containing source-level metadata.
Single MethodInterceptor. A single MethodInterceptor is used to proxy one or more bean definitions.

sect3.title: Proxy Factory
sect3.para: Let's use EHCache as our cache provider:
sect3.programlisting: 1 <bean id="cacheProvider" 2 class="org.springmodules.cache.provider.ehcache.EhcacheFacade"> 3 <property name="cacheManager" ref="cacheManager" /> 4 5 <!-- Cache profiles specified as a java.util.Properties --> 6 <property name="cacheProfiles"> 7 <props> 8 <prop key="first">[cacheName=firstCache]</prop> 9 <prop key="second">[cacheName=secondCache]</prop> 10 </props> 11 </property> 12 </bean>
sect3.para: Now we need to set up the proxy factory, CacheProxyFactoryBean:

para.programlisting: 13 <bean id="cacheable" 14 class="org.springmodules.cache.interceptor.proxy.CacheProxyFactoryBean"> 15 <property name="cacheProviderFacade" ref="cacheProvider" /> 16 <property name="cachingAttributes"> 17 <props> 18 <!-- We are going to cache the return value of the methods which names start with "get" --> 19 <prop key="get*">[cacheProfileId=first]</prop> 20 </props> 21 </property> 22 <property name="cacheFlushAttributes"> 23 <props> 24 <!-- We are going to flush the cache when the methods which names start with "update" are executed --> 25 <prop key="update*">[cacheProfileIds=first,second][flushBeforeExecution=true]</prop> 26 </props> 27 </property> 28 <property name="target"> 29 <!-- The bean to proxy --> 30 <bean class="org.springmodules.cache.integration.CacheableImpl"> 31 <property name="names"> 32 <list> 33 <value>James Gosling</value> 34 </list> 35 </property> 36 </bean> 37 </property> 38 </bean>

sect3.para: On line 19 we are telling the proxy factory to store in the cache "firstCache" the return value of the methods that start with "get". The id "first" is a reference to the cache profile defined on line 8.

On line 25 we are telling the proxy factory to flush the caches "firstCache" and "secondCache" after the methods that start with "update" are executed. The ids "first" and "second" are references to the cache profiles defined on lines 8 and 9 respectively.

sect3.title: Metadata-driven Autoproxy
sect3.para: Let's use JCS as our cache provider:

para.programlisting: 1 <bean id="cacheProvider" 2 class="org.springmodules.cache.provider.jcs.JcsFacade"> 3 <property name="cacheManager" ref="cacheManager" /> 4 5 <!-- Cache profiles specified as a java.util.Properties --> 6 <property name="cacheProfiles"> 7 <props> 8 <prop key="first">[cacheName=firstCache][group=aGroup]</prop> 9 <prop key="second">[cacheName=secondCache][group=anotherGroup]</prop> 10 </props> 11 </property> 12 </bean>

sect3.para: Autoproxy lets Spring "automagically" proxy beans definitions:
The metadata processor retrieves the source-level metadata which specifies the methods of the bean definitions that should be part of the caching services:
The caching advisor tells "autoproxy" to create proxies only for the bean definitions containing source-level metadata for caching:
sect3.programlisting:
<bean id="cachingAttributeSource" class="org.springmodules.cache.interceptor.caching.MetadataCachingAttributeSource"> <property name="attributes" ref="attributes" /> </bean>
<bean id="cachingInterceptor" class="org.springmodules.cache.interceptor.caching.CachingInterceptor"> <property name="cacheProviderFacade" ref="cacheProvider" /> <property name="cachingAttributeSource" ref="cachingAttributeSource" /> </bean>
<bean id="cachingAttributeSourceAdvisor" class="org.springmodules.cache.interceptor.caching.CachingAttributeSourceAdvisor"> <constructor-arg ref="cachingInterceptor" /> </bean>
sect3.para: The cache-flush advisor tells "autoproxy" to create proxies only for the bean definitions containing source-level metadata for flushing the cache:
sect3.programlisting:
<bean id="cacheFlushAttributeSource" class="org.springmodules.cache.interceptor.flush.MetadataCacheFlushAttributeSource"> <property name="attributes" ref="attributes" /> </bean>
<bean id="cacheFlushInterceptor" class="org.springmodules.cache.interceptor.flush.CacheFlushInterceptor"> <property name="cacheProviderFacade" ref="cacheProvider" /> <property name="cacheFlushAttributeSource" ref="cacheFlushAttributeSource" /> </bean>
<bean id="cacheFlushAttributeSourceAdvisor" class="org.springmodules.cache.interceptor.flush.CacheFlushAttributeSourceAdvisor"> <constructor-arg ref="cacheFlushInterceptor" /> </bean>
sect3.para: Now we define the bean(s) to proxy:
The defined beans must have source-level metadata attributes for caching and flushing the cache in order to be proxied. The following is the source code of the bean defined on line 47:

On line 103 of the Java source we are telling the caching advisor to store in the group "aGroup" of the cache "firstCache" the return value of the method "getName(int)." The id "first" is a reference to the cache profile defined on line 8 of the Spring configuration file.

On line 112 of the Java source we are telling the cache-flush advisor to flush the entries in the group "aGroup" of the cache "firstCache" and the entries of the group "anotherGroup" of the cache "secondCache" after the method "updateName(int, String)" is executed. The ids "first" and "second" are references to the cache profiles defined on lines 8 and 9 of the Spring configuration file respectively.

sect3.title: Reusing a single MethodInterceptor
sect3.para: Let's use OSCache as our cache provider:

para.programlisting: 1 <bean id="cacheProvider" 2 class="org.springmodules.cache.provider.oscache.OscacheFacade"> 3 <property name="cacheManager" ref="cacheManager" /> 4 5 <!-- Cache profiles specified as a java.util.Properties --> 6 <property name="cacheProfiles"> 7 <props> 8 <prop key="first">[cronExpression=* * * * *][groups=firstGroup][refreshPeriod=600]</prop> 9 <prop key="second">[groups=secondGroup]</prop> 10 </props> 11 </property> 12 </bean>

sect3.para: We need to register custom PropertyEditors in Spring:
Now it is possible to use a single CachingInterceptor and CacheFlushInterceptor to many beans and have a full control of the methods to advise:
sect3.programlisting: 30 <bean id="cachingInterceptor" 31 class="org.springmodules.cache.interceptor.caching.CachingInterceptor"> 32 <property name="cacheProviderFacade" ref="cacheProvider" /> 33 <property name="cachingAttributeSource"> 34 org.springmodules.cache.integration.CacheableImpl.get*=[cacheProfileId=first] 35 </property> 36 </bean> 37 38 <bean id="cacheFlushInterceptor" 39 class="org.springmodules.cache.interceptor.caching.CacheFlushInterceptor"> 40 <property name="cacheProviderFacade" ref="cacheProvider" /> 41 <property name="cacheFlushAttributeSource"> 42 org.springmodules.cache.integration.CacheableImpl.update*=[cacheProfileIds=first,second][flushBeforeExecution=true] 43 </property> 44 </bean>
sect3.para: On line 34 we are telling the caching interceptor to store in the group "firstGroup" (with the cron expression "* * * * *" and the refresh period of 600 seconds) the return value of the methods that start with "get" of a bean of class org.springmodules.cache.integration.CacheableImpl. The id "first" is a reference to the cache profile defined on line 8.

On line 42 we are telling the cache-flush interceptor to flush the groups "firstGroup" and "secondGroup" after the methods that start with "update" of a bean of class org.springmodules.cache.integration.CacheableImpl are executed. The ids "first" and "second" are references to the cache profiles defined on lines 8 and 9 respectively.
Now we need to proxy the bean(s):
sect3.programlisting:
<!-- Auto proxy --> <bean class="org.springframework.aop.framework.autoproxy.BeanNameAutoProxyCreator"> <property name="beanNames" value="cacheable" / <property name="interceptorNames"> <list> <value>cachingInterceptor</value> <value>cacheFlushInterceptor</value> </list> </property> </bean>
<!-- Bean to proxy --> <bean id="cacheable" class="org.springmodules.cache.integration.CacheableImpl"> <property name="names"> <list> <value>James Gosling</value> </list> </property> </bean>

sect2.title: Programmatic Use
sect2.para: Let's use EHCache as our cache provider:
sect2.programlisting: 1 <bean id="cacheProvider" 2 class="org.springmodules.cache.provider.ehcache.EhcacheFacade"> 3 <property name="cacheManager" ref="cacheManager" /> 4 5 <!-- Cache profiles specified as a java.util.Properties --> 6 <property name="cacheProfiles"> 7 <props> 8 <prop key="first">[cacheName=firstCache]</prop> 9 <prop key="second">[cacheName=secondCache]</prop> 10 </props> 11 </property> 12 </bean>
sect2.para: Obtain a reference to the cache provider (the bean "cacheProvider" in our example), which should be an implementation of the interface org.springmodules.cache.provider.CacheProviderFacade. This interface exposes the following methods:
